column1: Spain gained control of the Louisiana Territory west of the Mississippi River following the 1763 defeat of the French in the Seven Years' War; the British took over all territory to the east
column2: as well as Canada.The first permanent European settler in what is now Dubuque was Quebecois pioneer Julien Dubuque
column4: he received permission from the Spanish government and the local Meskwaki American Indians to mine the area's rich lead deposits. Control of Louisiana and Dubuque's mines shifted briefly back to France in 1800
column5: then to the United States in 1803
column6: following the Louisiana Purchase. Dubuque died in 1810. The Meskwaki continued to mine with the full support of the U.S. government until 1830 when the Meskwaki were illegally pushed out of the mine region by American prospectors.

column1: The current City of Dubuque was named after Julien Dubuque

column4: the city became home to numerous industries. Dubuque became a center for the timber industry because of its proximity to forests in Minnesota and Wisconsin
column5: and was later dominated by various millworking businesses. Also important were boat building
column6: brewing

column1: Dubuque's North End area was first settled in the late 19th century by working-class German immigrants. The German-American community sought to establish German Catholic churches separate from the Irish Catholic churches downtown and in the South End. The area retains its working-class roots and is home to some of Dubuque's largest factories.

It is affiliated with Mercy Medical Center — Dubuque

column17: Medical Associates Health Plans. Affiliated with the Finley Hospital is Dubuque Internal Medicine
column18: which as of 2007 was Iowa's largest internal medicine group practice clinic.

column1: Dubuque is served by four U.S. Highways (20
column4: 3. Highway 20 is the city's busiest east–west thoroughfare
column5: connecting to Rockford (and I-39/I-90) and Chicago to the east
column6: over the Julien Dubuque Bridge. In the west
column7: it connects to Waterloo. Highways 151 and 61 run north–south through the city
column8: with a shared expressway for part of the route. Highways 52 and 61 both connect Dubuque with the Twin Cities (Minnesota) to the north
column9: with 61 connecting to Davenport (and I-74/I-80)
column10: and 52 connecting to Bellevue to the south and then Clinton via U.S. Route 67. Highway 151 connects Dubuque with Madison
column11: Wisconsin (and I-39/I-90/I-94) (via the Dubuque–Wisconsin Bridge) to the northeast and Cedar Rapids to the southwest. Dubuque has four-lane
column12: divided highway connections with Cedar Rapids

column1: Iowa State Highway 3 begins in Dubuque
column2: connecting the city with central and western Iowa. The four-lane divided Northwest Arterial (former Iowa State Highway 32) acts as a beltway for parts of the North End and West Side
column3: connecting Highways 3 and 20. Less than two miles (3.2 km) from the junction of the Northwest Arterial and Highway 20
column4: the Southwest Arterial is a 6.1-mile (9.8 km) expressway carrying Highway 52 southeast from Highway 20 to Highways 151 and 61 near Key West and the Dubuque Regional Airport.

column1: Dubuque and its region are served by the general-aviation Dubuque Regional Airport (IATA: DBQ
column2: ICAO: KDBQ). The airport currently has one carrier
column4: (a division of American Airlines) which operates three non-stop jet flights daily to Chicago O'Hare International Airport. Northwest Airlines regional partner Mesaba operating under Northwest Airlink used to have daily service to Dubuque. Northwest operated twice daily flights to and from Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport (IATA: MSP
column5: ICAO: KMSP) using Saab 340 aircraft. These flights began June 2008 and ended on August 31
column6: 2009. Northwest Airlines offered service to Dubuque prior to 9/11.

column2: the City of Dubuque
column3: continues to court additional carriers to add service to the airport. The Dubuque Regional Airport has reported steadily increasing passenger numbers over the years
column4: and
column6: had service from three different carriers prior to 9/11. In early November 2007
column7: it was announced that October 2007 was the best month ever for American Eagle airline at the Dubuque Regional Airport
column8: according to Robert Grierson
column9: Dubuque Regional Airport manager: "We had 4
column10: 510 total revenue passenger enplanements; that is a record for American Eagle in Dubuque. American Eagle averaged a 79.82 percent enplanement load factor. Load factors are determined by how many revenue passengers were on the plane versus how many seats are available."Currently
column11: a $23 million new terminal is being built to modernize and expand the airport. Improvements include a larger terminal
column13: and expanded aviation parking. The new terminal at the Dubuque Regional Airport was expected to open in 2016.

column2: public transportation is provided by the city transit division The Jule. The Jule operates multiple daytime bus routes
column3: late night Friday and Saturday bus routes and Minibus service
column4: summer trolleys
column5: and on-demand paratransit Minibus service throughout the city. The routes are based out of one or more of the three transfer locations and run in 30-minute loops. These loops serve neighborhoods
column6: shopping areas
column7: medical offices
column8: and industrial parks and provide connections to other areas of the city with the 15-minute cross-town Express route. The system's three major transfer stations are Downtown Intermodal (9th & Elm St)
column9: Midtown (North Grandview & University Avenues)
column10: and the West End (Kennedy Circle/John F. Kennedy Road).
